articles.headline: The Fever for Exotic Stocks
articles.snippet: Four years into the longest bull market in the brief history of investing in emerging markets, investors have shown a willingness to take on risk.
articles.abstract: Four years into the longest bull market in the brief history of investing in emerging markets, investors have shown a willingness to take on risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Simon Nocera runs a hedge fund that invests in emerging markets, and so, perhaps not surprisingly, prides himself on having a keen appetite for risk. But even he had to draw the line when his broker tried to get him into Zambian treasury bills.

articles.headline: May's Treo Leapfrogs Past January's
articles.snippet: Good things come to those who wait. The Treo 700P smartphone is the Windows Treo without the Windows, and it's almost everything you'd wish it to be.
articles.abstract: Good things come to those who wait. The Treo 700P smartphone is the Windows Treo without the Windows, and it's almost everything you'd wish it to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE electronics industry operates like a very expensive game of leapfrog. You buy something in April, and then a newer, faster, less expensive version comes out in May. Rats!

articles.headline: U.S. Said to Weigh a New Approach on North Korea
articles.snippet: The new plan would start negotiations on a peace treaty in parallel with efforts to dismantle the country's nuclear program.
articles.abstract: The new plan would start negotiations on a peace treaty in parallel with efforts to dismantle the country's nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 17  President Bush's top advisers have recommended a broad new approach to dealing with North Korea that would include beginning negotiations on a peace treaty, even while efforts to dismantle the country's nuclear program are still under way, senior administration officials and Asian diplomats say.

articles.headline: Giving Galilee a Foothold in Industry
articles.snippet: Warren Buffett's $4 billion investment in Iscar Metalworking Company has provided a positive jolt to Israel's financial community.
articles.abstract: Warren Buffett's $4 billion investment in Iscar Metalworking Company has provided a positive jolt to Israel's financial community.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEFEN INDUSTRIAL PARK, Israel, May 15 — Warren E. Buffett, the multibillionaire investor, put up $4 billion to buy 80 percent of the Iscar Metalworking Company without bothering to visit its hilltop headquarters here in the isolated Galilee region of northern Israel. He missed quite a trip.

articles.headline: And if It's a Boy, Will It Be Lleh?
articles.snippet: Nevaeh, which is Heaven spelled backward, is now a more popular name for baby girls than Sara and Vanessa.
articles.abstract: Nevaeh, which is Heaven spelled backward, is now a more popular name for baby girls than Sara and Vanessa.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chances are you don't have any friends named Nevaeh. Chances are today's toddlers will.

articles.headline: Inflation Rising, Markets Tumble
articles.snippet: Behind the market's reversal is a growing concern that inflation may not be firmly under control.
articles.abstract: Behind the market's reversal is a growing concern that inflation may not be firmly under control.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a week ago, the Dow Jones industrial average was on the verge of a record high. Without much fanfare, the Dow — the best-known indicator of the stock market's performance — seemed about to regain all that had been lost since the spectacular 1990's boom came to an end.

articles.headline: Inflation Rising, Markets Tumble
articles.snippet: Only a week ago, the Dow Jones industrial average was on the verge of a record high. Without much fanfare, the Dow -- the best-known indicator of the stock market's performance -- seemed about to regain all that had been lost since the spectacular...
articles.abstract: Only a week ago, the Dow Jones industrial average was on the verge of a record high. Without much fanfare, the Dow -- the best-known indicator of the stock market's performance -- seemed about to regain all that had been lost since the spectacular 1990's boom came to an end.      But nearly every trading day since last week's high-water mark, stocks have fallen, and yesterday they really tumbled on a government report that showed consumer prices rising more than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a week ago, the Dow Jones industrial average was on the verge of a record high. Without much fanfare, the Dow -- the best-known indicator of the stock market's performance -- seemed about to regain all that had been lost since the spectacular 1990's boom came to an end.

articles.headline: Giving Galilee a Foothold in Industry
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett, the multibillionaire investor, put up $4 billion to buy 80 percent of the Iscar Metalworking Company without bothering to visit its hilltop headquarters here in the isolated Galilee region of northern Israel. He missed quite a t...
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett, the multibillionaire investor, put up $4 billion to buy 80 percent of the Iscar Metalworking Company without bothering to visit its hilltop headquarters here in the isolated Galilee region of northern Israel. He missed quite a trip.      Since its founding on the Wertheimer family's kitchen porch in 1952, Iscar, which makes precision metal-cutting tools for a wide range of industries, has been led by a fiercely independent father-and-son team, Stef and Eitan Wertheimer, who have always operated well outside the business mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEFEN INDUSTRIAL PARK, Israel, May 15 - Warren E. Buffett, the multibillionaire investor, put up $4 billion to buy 80 percent of the Iscar Metalworking Company without bothering to visit its hilltop headquarters here in the isolated Galilee region of northern Israel. He missed quite a trip.

articles.headline: Questions for C.I.A. Pick
articles.snippet: When Gen. Michael V. Hayden testifies at a Senate hearing today, he could be questioned about his appearance last year. Page A22.
articles.abstract: When Gen. Michael V. Hayden testifies at a Senate hearing today, he could be questioned about his appearance last year. Page A22.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Gen. Michael V. Hayden testifies at a Senate hearing today, he could be questioned about his appearance last year. Page A22.

articles.headline: Colleges Chase as Cheats Shift to Higher Tech
articles.snippet: At the University of California at Los Angeles, a student loaded his class notes into a handheld e-mail device and tried to read them during an exam; a classmate turned him in. At the journalism school at San Jose State University, students were c...
articles.abstract: At the University of California at Los Angeles, a student loaded his class notes into a handheld e-mail device and tried to read them during an exam; a classmate turned him in. At the journalism school at San Jose State University, students were caught using spell check on their laptops when part of the exam was designed to test their ability to spell.     And at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, after students photographed test questions with their cellphone cameras, transmitted them to classmates outside the exam room and got the answers back in text messages, the university put in place a new proctoring system.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - At the University of California at Los Angeles, a student loaded his class notes into a handheld e-mail device and tried to read them during an exam; a classmate turned him in. At the journalism school at San Jose State University, students were caught using spell check on their laptops when part of the exam was designed to test their ability to spell.

articles.headline: Bush Turns to Big Military Contractors for Border Control
articles.snippet: The quick fix may involve sending in the National Guard. But to really patch up the broken border, President Bush is preparing to turn to a familiar administration partner: the nation's giant military contractors.      Lockheed Martin, Raytheon an...
articles.abstract: The quick fix may involve sending in the National Guard. But to really patch up the broken border, President Bush is preparing to turn to a familiar administration partner: the nation's giant military contractors.      Lockheed Martin, Raytheon and Northrop Grumman, three of the largest, are among the companies that said they would submit bids within two weeks for a multibillion-dollar federal contract to build what the administration calls a ''virtual fence'' along the nation's land borders.

articles.headline: U.S. Said to Weigh a New Approach on North Korea
articles.snippet: President Bush's top advisers have recommended a broad new approach to dealing with North Korea that would include beginning negotiations on a peace treaty, even while efforts to dismantle the country's nuclear program are still under way, senior ...
articles.abstract: President Bush's top advisers have recommended a broad new approach to dealing with North Korea that would include beginning negotiations on a peace treaty, even while efforts to dismantle the country's nuclear program are still under way, senior administration officials and Asian diplomats say.     Aides say Mr. Bush is very likely to approve the new approach, which has been hotly debated among different factions within the administration. But he will not do so unless North Korea returns to multinational negotiations over its nuclear program. The talks have been stalled since September.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 17 - President Bush's top advisers have recommended a broad new approach to dealing with North Korea that would include beginning negotiations on a peace treaty, even while efforts to dismantle the country's nuclear program are still under way, senior administration officials and Asian diplomats say.

articles.headline: Wider Briefing For Lawmakers On Spy Efforts
articles.snippet: Classified briefings provided to lawmakers on Wednesday about a controversial domestic eavesdropping program have smoothed what might have been a contentious path toward confirmation for Gen. Michael V. Hayden as director of the Central Intelligen...
articles.abstract: Classified briefings provided to lawmakers on Wednesday about a controversial domestic eavesdropping program have smoothed what might have been a contentious path toward confirmation for Gen. Michael V. Hayden as director of the Central Intelligence Agency, senators and Congressional officials said.     The closed-door sessions in the Capitol, on the eve of a confirmation hearing for General Hayden, were the first time the White House had provided briefings to the full Senate and House Intelligence Committees about the program. As director of the National Security Agency until last year, General Hayden oversaw the surveillance program, whose existence came to light in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 17 - Classified briefings provided to lawmakers on Wednesday about a controversial domestic eavesdropping program have smoothed what might have been a contentious path toward confirmation for Gen. Michael V. Hayden as director of the Central Intelligence Agency, senators and Congressional officials said.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: From Asia to America, How Bausch's Crisis Grew
articles.snippet: Early in March, Bausch & Lomb received a troubling phone call from a New Jersey eye doctor. Dr. David S. Chu, a specialist in cornea diseases, alerted the company that three of his recent patients had been afflicted with a microbe that caused a po...
articles.abstract: Early in March, Bausch & Lomb received a troubling phone call from a New Jersey eye doctor. Dr. David S. Chu, a specialist in cornea diseases, alerted the company that three of his recent patients had been afflicted with a microbe that caused a potentially blinding eye infection.     All three, Dr. Chu said, had used Bausch & Lomb's ReNu brand lens cleaners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in March, Bausch & Lomb received a troubling phone call from a New Jersey eye doctor. Dr. David S. Chu, a specialist in cornea diseases, alerted the company that three of his recent patients had been afflicted with a microbe that caused a potentially blinding eye infection.

articles.headline: May's Treo Leapfrogs Past January's
articles.snippet: THE electronics industry operates like a very expensive game of leapfrog. You buy something in April, and then a newer, faster, less expensive version comes out in May. Rats!     On the other hand, you might get lucky; you might not buy in until t...
articles.abstract: THE electronics industry operates like a very expensive game of leapfrog. You buy something in April, and then a newer, faster, less expensive version comes out in May. Rats!     On the other hand, you might get lucky; you might not buy in until the better version comes along. There you sit on the train, on the plane or at the baseball field, smugly looking over at the poor saps who bought last month's phone, music player or camera.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Eases Audit Rules but Rejects Exemptions
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission moved yesterday to make audit rules that have angered many companies easier and less expensive to apply. But despite political pressure, the commission said smaller companies would eventually have to comply w...
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission moved yesterday to make audit rules that have angered many companies easier and less expensive to apply. But despite political pressure, the commission said smaller companies would eventually have to comply with rules governing their internal controls.     The commission also indicated that it would take at least two years to ensure that every public company was in compliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission moved yesterday to make audit rules that have angered many companies easier and less expensive to apply. But despite political pressure, the commission said smaller companies would eventually have to comply with rules governing their internal controls.

articles.headline: The Fever for Exotic Stocks
articles.snippet: Simon Nocera runs a hedge fund that invests in emerging markets, and so, perhaps not surprisingly, prides himself on having a keen appetite for risk. But even he had to draw the line when his broker tried to get him into Zambian treasury bills.   ...
articles.abstract: Simon Nocera runs a hedge fund that invests in emerging markets, and so, perhaps not surprisingly, prides himself on having a keen appetite for risk. But even he had to draw the line when his broker tried to get him into Zambian treasury bills.     ''It was pure, baseless speculation,'' said Mr. Nocera, who has been investing in developing markets for more than 15 years. ''If I am going to play the casinos, I would rather go to Las Vegas.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Simon Nocera runs a hedge fund that invests in emerging markets, and so, perhaps not surprisingly, prides himself on having a keen appetite for risk. But even he had to draw the line when his broker tried to get him into Zambian treasury bills.

articles.headline: And if It's a Boy, Will It Be Lleh?
articles.snippet: Chances are you don't have any friends named Nevaeh. Chances are today's toddlers will.     In 1999, there were only eight newborn American girls named Nevaeh. Last year, it was the 70th-most-popular name for baby girls, ahead of Sara, Vanessa and...
articles.abstract: Chances are you don't have any friends named Nevaeh. Chances are today's toddlers will.     In 1999, there were only eight newborn American girls named Nevaeh. Last year, it was the 70th-most-popular name for baby girls, ahead of Sara, Vanessa and Amanda.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chances are you don't have any friends named Nevaeh. Chances are today's toddlers will.
